description: Display of 1no. x non illuminated hanging sign with brand shield to each side
decision_conditions: No advertisement shall be displayed without the permission of the owner of the site or any other person with an interest in the site entitled to grant permission.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) Regulations 2007.

No advertisement shall be sited or displayed so as to -Endanger persons using any highway, railway, waterway, dock, harbour or aerodrome (civil or military);Obscure, or hinder the ready interpretation of any traffic sign, railway signal or aid to navigation by water or air; orHinder the operation of any device used for the purpose of security or surveillance or for measuring the speed of any vehicle.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) Regulations 2007.

Any advertisement displayed, and any site used for the display of advertisements, shall be maintained in a condition that does not impair the visual amenity of the site.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) Regulations 2007.

Any advertisement displayed, and any site used for the display of advertisements, shall be maintained in a condition that does not impair the visual amenity of the site.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) Regulations 2007.

Where an advertisement is required under the Regulations to be removed, the site shall be left in a condition that does not endanger the public or impair visual amenity.Reason: To comply with Regulation 14 of the Town and Country Planning (Control of Advertisements) (England) Regulations 2007.

The application site is located on the pavement on Davis Road at the juncture with Cox Lane which cuts through the Chessington Industrial Area a designated Strategic Industrial Location.The surrounding area is predominantly industrial. The site is not in a conservation area and the buildings and curtilage are not statutorily or locally listed. No objections received. The application seeks to determine whether the prior approval of the Local Planning Authority is required for the siting and appearance of the proposed installation of  a 20m high 5G telecoms: H3G street pole, additional equipment cabinets and associated works.The application has been assessed against the provisions of Schedule 2 Part 16 of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 as amended. The application has also been assessed against the policies of the National Planning Policy Framework and the current Development Plan policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy.The National Planning Policy Framework 2021 is clear at paragraph 118 in as much as the Local Planning Authority should not question need. Local planning authorities must determine applications on planning grounds only. They should not seek to prevent competition between different operators, question the need for an electronic communications system, or set health safeguards different from the International Commission guidelines for public exposure.This application is for prior approval, not for planning permission. Prior approval is a light-touch process which applies where the principle of the development has already been established (National Planning Practice Guidance) (Paragraph: 028 Reference ID: 13-028-20140306).Prior approval means that a developer has to seek approval from the local planning authority that specified elements of the development are acceptable before work can proceed. The matters for prior approval vary depending on the type of development and these are set out in full in the relevant parts in Schedule 2 to the General Permitted Development Order. A local planning authority cannot consider any other matters when determining a prior approval application (National Planning Practice Guidance) (Paragraph: 026 Reference ID: 13-026-20140306).The main considerations of the case are: - Siting and; - AppearanceThe proposed telecom apparatus would be sited in a highly visible location on the pavement on the corner of Davis Road at the juncture with Cox Lane .The height of the mast would be 20 m which would be in excess of 10 to 12m higher than a standard street lamp column (10m) and  telegraph pole (8m) which are typical other such perpendicular pieces of street furniture found in the locality. In addition the proposed would be 6.5m taller than the immediate adjacent buildings. It is considered that the proposal would not relate well to its surrounding and would result in an incongruous addition to the streetscene that would be visually intrusive and create visual clutter and detract from the character and appearance of the surrounding area. It is considered that the siting and appearance would be inappropriate in this case and it is recommended that prior approval be refused. Whilst not necessary we used the following policies to assit with the assessment CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.The need for an upgraded, modern telecommunications network is both acknowledged and appreciated, and indeed is given great weight in the decision making process; however, for the reasons cited above it is considered that the harm caused by the proposed installation would outweigh the benefits. In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably. Amendments required to make the application acceptable are substantial and would materially change the development proposal.  They would require further consultation to be undertaken prior to determination which could not take place within the statutory determination period specified by the Department of Communities and Local Government.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

The applicant is reminded that implementing the scheme subject of this application in combination with another development, whether pursuant to permitted development rights, a prior approval or a planning permission could render the totality of the works unlawful. This is particularly the case where the proposals would physically adjoin. The applicant is strongly advised to seek further advice before proceeding with any development.

Officers have assessed the information submitted, taking into account the nature of the development it is concluded that the information is acceptable to allow the discharge of condition 6 (Fire Safety Strategy) of Planning Permission 23/00387/HOU

Please complete and return section refering to 'Discharge of Conditions' on your application form as this has not been completed appropriately. Conditions 1, 2 and 3 are included in this sections which are conditions that do not require discharging as they are compliance conditions. Please submit a revised application form and any relevant details through the planning portal for the discharge of Condition 4 (Fire Safety).

Please provide Existing Sections at a recognised scale (at 1:50 or 1:100 for example), showing the outline of the entire property not just part and showing dimensions. Although the inclusion of a scale bar is not mandatory, it is highly encouraged.
